text: I fixed the problem of stacking by the next code.  If event.type == pygame.KEYUP:     If event.key == pygame.K_LEFT and x_change == -5:         x_change = 0     If event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT and x_change == +5:         x_change = 0

author: @oribarashy1
text: First off, love all your videos. Better than other things I've tried online, including a Udemy course... author: @bradley1048
text: Hey man, what a great series! I really appreciate these tutorials.  So, mine worked fine until I defined my game_loop() function. After that, I got no error messages or anything, just a grey screen with no content.  Here's my code: _________  import pygame  pygame.init()  display_width = 800 display_height = 600  black = (0,0,0) white = (255,255,255) grey = (105,105,105)  gameDisplay = pygame.display.set_mode((display_width, display_height)) pygame.display.set_caption('Racing Game') clock = pygame.time.Clock()  carImg = pygame.image.load('tank1.png') carImg = pygame.transform.scale(carImg,(100,108))  def car (x,y):     gameDisplay.blit(carImg,(x,y))   def game_loop():     x = (display_width * 0.45)     y = (display_height * 0.8)      x_change = 0      crashed = False      while not crashed:          for event in pygame.event.get():             if event.type == pygame.QUIT:                 crashed = True              if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:                 if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                     x_change = -5                 elif event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                     x_change = 5              if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:                 if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT or event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                     x_change = 0      x += x_change      gameDisplay.fill(grey)     car(x,y)              pygame.display.update()     clock.tick(60)  game_loop()     pygame.quit() quit()  _______  Did I miss something?

author: @Monkhaus
text: The below code makes the movement a lot smoother. It goes in the while loop (not the for loop), and replaces the event statements for the movement. Also, you won't need the extra variable x_change. Not sure if this is a better way of doing it though, but it is smoother.   pressed = pygame.key.get_pressed()         if pressed[pygame.K_RIGHT]: x += 5         if pressed[pygame.K_LEFT]: x += -5

author: @greenalien5509
text: I did mine a little differently...   key_right = False  key_left = False  while not gameExit:      for event in pygame.event.get():    if event.type == pygame.QUIT:     gameExit = True         if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:     if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:      key_left = True     elif event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:      key_right = True          if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:     if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:      key_left = False     if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:      key_right = False         if key_left == True and x > 0:    x += -5   if key_right == True and x < (display_width - 128):    x += 5  This way the car stops at the borders and holding both keys down at the same time works properly. :)

author: @ladyqonimvu8604
text: there is an error in coding .. of keys .. heres the way for event in pygame.event.get():               if event.type == QUIT:                      pygame.quit()                      sys.exit()               if event.type == KEYDOWN:                      if event.key == K_RIGHT:                             x_change =  5                      elif event.key == K_LEFT:                             x_change = -5         x = (x + x_change)
